prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about a couple where the guy pays all the bills and his girlfriend only works part-time. One incident happened where he asked her to pay for takeout because he left his wallet, and she reacted negatively. The author is considering making her start contributing more to the bills because of this.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The guy has been paying everything, which might have been an unspoken agreement. The girlfriend works part-time, so maybe she doesn't have a lot of income. The incident over $40 takeout made him feel like she wasn't contributing, leading him to want her to pay part of the bills.

Is the guy in the wrong? Well, if the agreement was always that he pays everything, then maybe this is a point of contention. But he's reacting to a single incident. The girlfriend's reaction might have been due to feeling like her contributions aren't acknowledged in other ways. Maybe she does other things around the house that he doesn't value. The author is overreacting to one event, which might not be fair. Also, making her pay bills because of a single incident seems harsh, especially if her income is limited. It's possible he's being unfair because one incident doesn't justify a big change in the financial arrangement. However, if he's been feeling unappreciated all along, maybe it's a valid point. But the question is about whether he's in the wrong. Since he's using a single incident to make a significant change without considering other factors, like her financial situation or their prior agreement, he might be the one in the wrong. So the answer is A.
